column1: Secaucus ( SEE-kaw-kəs) is a town in Hudson County
column2: New Jersey
column3: United States. As of the 2010 United States Census

column11: it is the most suburban of the county's municipalities

column15: as well as protected areas.Secaucus is a derivation of the Algonquian words for "black" (seke or sukit) and "snake" (achgook)

column2: once an island
column3: was part of the territory purchased by Director-General of New Netherland
column4: Peter Stuyvesant in 1658. The territory was part of what is considered to be the oldest municipality in the state of New Jersey which was first chartered in 1660 as Bergen in the province of New Netherland and
column6: became Bergen Township.

column1: Settlement had begun by at least 1733 by the Smith family
column2: whose namesake Abel I. Smith Burial Ground is part of the lore of Secaucus.Secaucus was originally formed as a borough by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on March 12
column4: from portions of North Bergen. On June 7
column6: Secaucus was incorporated as a town
column8: based on the results of a referendum held on June 5
column9: 1917.Secaucus was originally an agricultural community specializing in flowers. It later became known for its pig farms in the first half of the 20th century. In the early 1900s the town was home to approximately 55 pig farms
column12: which outnumbered humans 16 to 1. These farms served the meat demands of Newark and New York
column13: and made the farmers wealthy. Many of them were local politicians
column14: most notably pork peddler Henry B. Krajewski
column15: who ran for New Jersey senator
column16: three times for governor and twice for U.S. President. The town's pig farms
column18: and junk yards gave the town a reputation for being one of the most odorous in the New York metropolitan area. In the 1950s the pig farms began to dwindle
column19: partially due to construction on the New Jersey Turnpike
column20: which would carry tourists who would not appreciate the odor. In 1963
column21: debris from the demolition of Pennsylvania Station was dumped in the Secaucus Meadowlands. In later decades Secaucus became more of a commuter town. In a non-binding referendum in 1969
column22: 90% of voters in Secaucus chose to leave Hudson County and join Bergen County
column23: as that county was more similar in character and had lower taxes.  However
column24: only the state has the authority to change county lines
column25: so it never came to fruition. Today it remains the most suburban town in Hudson County. Despite being geographically located within Hudson County
column26: Secaucus Public Library is a member of the Bergen County Cooperative Library System.On February 9
column28: two NJ Transit commuter trains collided at Bergen Junction in Secaucus when a train operating on the Bergen Line ran a signal and sideswiped a train running on the Main Line. The accident occurred during the morning rush hour just south of the current Secaucus Junction station. With three fatalities
column29: the incident is NJ Transit's deadliest accident and was the first to involve fatalities of the passenger and crew on NJ Transit.New Jersey Monthly magazine ranked Secaucus as its 182nd best place to live in its 2010 rankings of the "Best Places To Live" in New Jersey
column30: after ranking the borough 11th in its 2008 rankings.

column6: Secaucus provides opportunities to observe the recovery of natural marshes in the town's post-industrial
column7: post-agricultural age. Some marsh areas in the northeast part of town have been filled to provide a new commercial area
column8: and some to build footpaths for nature walks with signs illustrating birds and other wildlife to be seen there. At 27.4%
column9: it has the most open "green" space in of any town in Hudson County.Secaucus borders the municipalities of Jersey City

column1: Harmon Cove is the western section of Secaucus
column2: New Jersey along the Hackensack River
column3: south of New Jersey Route 3. The name is portmanteau taken from Hartz Mountain
column4: a corporation that owns much land in the New Jersey Meadowlands
column5: which originally developed the area as a gated community in the 1970s with townhouses and highrise residential buildings. Part of the Hackensack RiverWalk Secaucus Greenway passes through the neighborhood

column7: home to Hudson County's Laurel Hill Park.

column1: NJ Transit maintained a Harmon Cove station from 1978 until the re-routing of the Bergen County Line and the opening of Secaucus Junction in August 2003. The HX Draw is used by the line to cross the river. NJ Transit bus 329 serves the area. The Hudson Regional Hospital and several hotels are located in Harmon Cove
column2: whose main thoroughfare is Meadowlands Parkway
column3: along which office and manufacturing buildings are found. The Harmon Cove Outlet Center is an outlet shopping district further inland from the Hackensack riverfront. Hartz Mountain Industries operates many facilities and properties in Harmon Cove.

column1: There are several large retail areas in Secaucus. Secaucus Plaza is the "downtown" area of Secaucus
column2: just off of Route 3. The Outlets are a collection of outlet shops selling discounted name-brand merchandise in southwest Secaucus. Many factory retail outlets are scattered throughout the Harmon Cove industrial section
column3: often located in warehouses or converted factories. Harmon Cove Outlet Center is the largest outlet mall
column4: on Enterprise Avenue. The Mill Creek Mall is a mall on Route 3 on the west side of the Turnpike. Harmon Meadow Plaza is a large hotel
column5: restaurant and shopping complex that features gyms
column6: a pool hall
column8: a 14-screen Showplace Theatres and a Wal-Mart and Sam's Club located east of the New Jersey Turnpike
column9: near Route 3 and Interchange 16E. Best Buy
column12: Home Depot and Daffy's are located on Paterson Plank Road off Interchange 16E. National Retail Systems is another large employer. Secaucus is home to several corporate headquarters
column15: Hartz Mountain Industries and Quest Diagnostics.Goya Foods previously had its headquarters there.In 2011
column16: two companies announced that they would be leaving Secaucus. The Manischewitz Company announced that it would relocate its administrative offices to Newark after being located in Secaucus for seven years. Panasonic's North American headquarters
column22: had been located in Secaucus since 1973. After considering new locations in New York
column24: the company announced it would relocate to Newark and would receive an Urban Transit Hub Tax Credit of $102 million from the State of New Jersey for the relocation 8 miles (13 km) from its Secaucus location. The company also cited the environmental benefits possible by reducing the need of 1

column2: Secaucus became the official review headquarters of the National Basketball Association. All reviews of controversial calls and plays take place in the replay center. Referees consult the headquarters for guidance on the correct call. The high-tech center features over 94 HD televisions
column3: with multiple feeds of every live NBA game.Sports companies headquartered in Secaucus include Red Bull New York
column4: Major League Baseball's MLB Network
column6: and NBA Entertainment/NBA TV (whose studios are also the site of the NBA Draft Lottery). It is also home to men's soccer team Secaucus FC
column7: which is part of the Garden State Soccer League
column8: and was founded in 2003 by Nick Farinola.Secaucus was the headquarters of Major League Lacrosse for the first four seasons of the league. The headquarters have since moved to Boston
column9: Massachusetts.Secaucus held a pre-Super Bowl "Winter Blast" party during the first weekend of February 2014 to celebrate Super Bowl XLVIII being played in New Jersey. The party featured a number of activities
column10: including an ice skating rink. The town had planned for large crowds
column11: even planning special court sessions in advance to handle the projected surge of potentially disruptive visitors. The turnout was much lower than expected
column12: with Mayor Gonnelli citing the NFL's focus on activities in Manhattan aimed at visitors.

column1: Secaucus is governed under the Town form of New Jersey municipal government. The town is one of nine municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this traditional form of government. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the Town Council made up of six council members elected from three wards. A Mayor is elected at-large directly by the voters. The Town Council is comprised of six members elected to serve four-year terms on a staggered basis
column2: with three seats up at the same time as the mayor and three seats the following year
column3: followed by two years with no elections.As of 2020
column4: the Mayor of Secaucus is Independent Michael Gonnelli
column5: whose term of office ends December 31
column6: 2021. Members of the Town Council are James J. Clancy Sr. (I
column16: 2022; Ward 3).Orietta Tringali was chosen in January 2018 to fill the Ward 3 seat expiring in December 2018 that had been held by Susan Pirro until she resigned from office. On June 9
column17: 2018 the Office of Emergency Management Building was dedicated to former Councilwoman Susan Pirro who died on March 18

column1: Secaucus contains a wide variety of road and rail transportation. Because of its central location
column2: many shipping warehouses and truck freight transfer stations are located in Secaucus
column3: both for shipping companies such as UPS and for numerous retailers. For example
column4: Barnes & Noble's "same day delivery" service to Manhattan operates from a warehouse in Secaucus. The town also has a large rail yard and multimode terminal run by CSX and Norfolk Southern where loads are switched between trains or transferred to or from trucks.

column2: the town had a total of 47.16 miles (75.90 km) of roadways
column3: of which 38.08 miles (61.28 km) were maintained by the municipality
column4: 2.56 miles (4.12 km) by Hudson County and 1.75 miles (2.82 km) by the New Jersey Department of Transportation and 4.77 miles (7.68 km) by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.The town is roughly divided into four parts by the intersecting roads of Route 3
column6: and the Eastern Spur of the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95)
column7: which runs north–south. Two turnpike interchanges are located within the town: Exit 16E/17 for Route 3 and Route 495 (which leads to the Lincoln Tunnel)
column8: and Exit 15X for the Secaucus Junction station (which opened in late 2005).

column1: Secaucus is the site of NJ Transit's Frank R. Lautenberg Secaucus Junction rail station
column2: which connects NJ Transit's two commuter rail networks in northern New Jersey. As the station is in the south end of the town
column3: access from the rest of Secaucus is limited via County Avenue
column4: Meadowlands Parkway or NJ Turnpike Interchange 15X. The station opened in December 2003
column6: 100-spot parking lot that allows commuters to park and ride. Discount curbside intercity bus service is also provided outside the station by Megabus
column7: with direct service to Boston and Philadelphia
column8: among other locations.Numerous NJ Transit buses serve Secaucus
column11: 190 and 320 buses to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown Manhattan
column14: the 85 route to Hoboken and local service provided on the 772 route. There is a bus park-and-ride at the northeast corner of Secaucus.In the first half of the 20th century the Jersey City
column15: Hoboken and Rutherford Electric Railway operated a trolley line through the then main business district of Secaucus
column16: on Paterson Plank Road from Jersey City and across the Hackensack River to East Rutherford.The closest airport with scheduled passenger service is Newark Liberty International Airport
column17: which straddles Newark and Elizabeth. The nearest intercity rail station is New York Penn Station
column18: a one-seat ride from Secaucus Junction.
